awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Precision Tests of Physics Beyond the Standard Model with Antihydrogen
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research, part of the ALPHA Collaboration, is to search for differences between the properties of hydrogen and antihydrogen, the antimatter counterpart to hydrogen.  According to very general principles that underlie our mathematical description of the physical world, the atomic physics of antihydrogen should be identical to that of hydrogen. Any differences in the atomic physics or gravitational dynamics between antihydrogen and hydrogen would challenge the very basis of established mathematical descriptions of the world around us. The collaboration's high-precision measurements may shed light on one of the most important questions in physics, known as the baryon asymmetry, which is the preponderance of matter over antimatter in the observable universe.  This award is made under the NSF/DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering and will support the collaboration's effort at Purdue University and an undergraduate student at University of California, Berkeley as complementary to a DOE award made under the joint program. 
 
The goal of this research, part of the ALPHA Collaboration, is to search for differences between the properties of hydrogen and antihydrogen; such differences could only result from Charge-Parity-Time (CPT) or Weak Equivalence Principle violation. The ALPHA collaboration at CERN has progressed from trapping antihydrogen to measuring its positron spin flip frequency, somewhat crudely its gravitational properties, its charge neutrality, its 1S-2S spectrum, and its hyperfine spectrum.  Significant improvement in the precision of all these measurements is expected during the duration of this funding period. In the near term, ALPHA is constructing, and is expected to install, a new vertical experimental apparatus, ALPHAg, to conduct an up/down gravity measurement. In parallel, it will continue measurements on the optical and hyperfine spectra of antihydrogen. During the upcoming two-year CERN shutdown, ALPHA will fully prepare ALPHAg and will build a new atomic spectrum trap, ALPHA-III.  During the final two years of funding, plans call for carrying out high-precision measurements utilizing fine scale magnetometry for gravity measurements at the 1% level; and applying laser and adiabatic cooling for high-precision measurements of the Lamb shift, the anti-Rydberg constant, charge neutrality, and the hyperfine spectrum.  Moreover, unlike many CPT tests, ALPHA's tests are model-independent and do not presume a particular CPT breaking mechanism

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported research conducted at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in Geneva, Switzerland, as part of the Antihydrogen Laser PHysics Apparatus (ALPHA) collaboration.  ALPHA investigates whether hydrogen atoms and antihydrogen atoms, the antimatter counterpart to hydrogen, consisting of a bound state of an antiproton paired with an anti-electron, or positron, behave identically in terms of interaction with electromagnetic radiation, as predicted by the Charge-Parity-Time Reversal (CPT) Theorem, and with respect to gravitational interactions with the Earth, as demanded by the Weak Equivalence Principle.  These constraints require that hydrogen and antihydrogen share the same absorption spectrum and experience the same gravitational acceleration.  Any deviation would challenge the fundamental framework of physical laws. High-precision measurements of antihydrogen may shed light on one of physics' most profound puzzles, namely the baryon asymmetry problem, or why the observable universe contains far more matter than antimatter, despite the expectation that they were created in equal amounts during the Big Bang.

The ALPHA collaboration, with Berkeley having a major role, designed, built, and operated a new vertical experimental apparatus called ALPHA-g. This groundbreaking device enabled the first direct observation of Earth's gravitational influence on antimatter.  Although some speculated that antimatter might exhibit "antigravity" and rise instead of fall, ALPHA's measurements definitively show that antihydrogen is pulled downward, ruling out any notion of a repulsive gravity between antimatter and ordinary matter. These results reinforce the prevailing understanding of gravity, confirming that antimatter behaves similarly to ordinary matter in Earth's gravitational field. To date, ALPHA-g has measured the gravitational constant for antimatter to be 0.75 g with combined statistical and systematic uncertainties of +- 0.29 g. This result is within error bars of 1 g, where g is the standard acceleration due to Earth's gravity. This gravity measurement appeared in the journal Nature in 2023: Observation of the effect of gravity on the motion of antimatter.

Future experiments with ALPHAg aim to enhance measurement precision, for example, by trapping hydrogen and antihydrogen simultaneously in the ALPHA-g apparatus. This setup will allow for direct, in situ, comparisons of their gravitational acceleration under identical conditions, effectively canceling out systematic uncertainties and improving the reliability of the results. 

The Berkeley team made leading contributions to new methods to control both the precursor anti-proton and positron plasmas and the trapped antihydrogen atoms which, along with key advances such as buffer-gas and laser cooling, led to a greater than order-of-magnitude increase in the trapping rates of antihydrogen; ALPHA now conducts experiments with thousands of anti-atoms in its traps and over the roughly half-year of antiproton availability now traps well over one hundred thousand anti-atoms.  Plasma-based magnetic field measurements using techniques developed at Berkeley attained parts-per-million precision and they were critical to understanding systematic errors in gravity experiments. The ALPHA collaboration has a second major apparatus where, among a host of experiments, we measured the antihydrogen 1S-2S transition to parts-per-trillion precision, demonstrated laser cooling of antihydrogen, and, at lesser precision, studied other aspects of antihydrogen "positronic" structure, including its hyperfine spectrum.  These advances over the last five years have led to an exciting vision of antihydrogen experiments that can rival the precision obtained in hydrogen studies and open a new era of neutral antimatter physics.

The award supported over a dozen Berkeley undergraduates who worked on the assembly and running of the ALPHA-g experiment, three graduate students conducted their thesis research on ALPHA, and two postdoctoral researchers led aspects of the experimental campaigns and data analysis, and developed new ideas for future experiments.

A detailed overview of the ALPHA experiment and our physics results is on our website.
